Problem:
Consider a system of first-order differential equations where the rate of change of a vector function \\(z(t)\\) is governed by \\(\\dot{z} = Mz + N\\), with \\(M\\) being a constant matrix and \\(N\\) a constant vector. The system is affected by a transformation defined by \\( g(z) = Qz + R \\), where \\(Q\\) is a constant matrix and \\(R\\) a constant vector.

If transformation \\( g(z) \\) is applied to a vector \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0 and then allowed to evolve under \\(\\dot{z} = Mz + N\\) without further intervention, will \\( z(T) \\) at T be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved to T under \\(\\dot{z} = Mz + N\\)?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \\( g(z) \\) modifies the initial conditions by mapping \\( z_0 \\) to \\( Qz_0 + R \\) before the differential equation begins to evolve it. This initial modification alters the trajectory and leads to a different state at time T than would occur from evolving \\( z_0 \\) directly.
